fields.value: Replication Data for: Women's Issues and Their Fates in the United States Congress

dsDescriptionValue.value: Significant scholarship indicates that female legislators focus their attention on “women’s issues” to a greater extent than do male lawmakers.  Drawing on over forty years of bill sponsorship data from the U.S. House of Representatives, we define women’s issues in terms of those sponsored at a greater rate by women in Congress.  Our analysis reveals that most (but not all) of the classically considered women’s issues are indeed raised at an enhanced rate by congresswomen.  We then track the fate of those issues.  While 4% of all bills become law, that rate drops to 2% for women’s issues and to only 1% for women’s issue bills sponsored by women themselves.  This pattern persists over time – from the early 1970s through today – and upon controlling for other factors that influence bills success rates.  We link the bias against women’s issues to the committee process, and suggest several avenues for further research.

fields.value: The files include the data to replicate all figures and tables in the paper, a stata .do file to undertake those replications, and an excel file that provides the data and calculations for Table 1 in the paper

files.description: This is an excel spreadsheet that provides the data that is used to create Figure 1 in the published paper, "Women's Issues and Their Fates in the United States Congress" (with the figure embedded into the spreadsheet)
files.label: PSRM_figure_1_VWW_data.tab

dataFile.description: This is an excel spreadsheet that provides the data that is used to create Figure 1 in the published paper, "Women's Issues and Their Fates in the United States Congress" (with the figure embedded into the spreadsheet)

files.description: This is the Stata .do file that uses data written in VWW_PSRM_2016_Replication_Dataset_Stata11.tab to replicate analysis and calculations that are presented in Tables and Figures in paper; it also provides explicit documentation for how to engage in calculations to create Figures 1-3.
